articles.headline: X May Lose Up to $75 Million in Revenue as More Advertisers Pull Out
articles.snippet: Internal documents show companies like Airbnb, Coca-Cola and Microsoft have halted ads, or may do so, after Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory.
articles.abstract: Internal documents show companies like Airbnb, Coca-Cola and Microsoft have halted ads, or may do so, after Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory.
articles.lead_paragraph: X, the social media company formerly known as Twitter, could lose as much as $75 million in advertising revenue by the end of the year as dozens of major brands pause their marketing campaigns after its owner, Elon Musk, endorsed an antisemitic conspiracy theory this month.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Kate Conger

articles.headline: First Captives Freed in Tense Gaza Truce Between Israel and Hamas
articles.snippet: Hamas freed two dozen hostages, Israel released 39 imprisoned Palestinians, and more than 130 aid trucks reached Gaza over the first day of a tense, temporary truce after seven weeks of war.
articles.abstract: Hamas freed two dozen hostages, Israel released 39 imprisoned Palestinians, and more than 130 aid trucks reached Gaza over the first day of a tense, temporary truce after seven weeks of war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hamas freed two dozen hostages held in Gaza and Israel released nearly 40 imprisoned Palestinians on Friday, completing the first exchange in a tense, temporary truce that halted the fighting after seven weeks of war.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Christina Goldbaum, Rami Nazzal and Alan Yuhas

articles.headline: Can Divorce Be Affordable? Yes, but Only if Spouses Want It to Be.
articles.snippet: There are ways to reduce the stress and expense of ending a marriage, but they require both parties to want to end the relationship civilly.
articles.abstract: There are ways to reduce the stress and expense of ending a marriage, but they require both parties to want to end the relationship civilly.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there is an easy point of agreement in the emotional upheaval of divorce, it is that endless legal battles can break the bank.

articles.headline: Despite Bans, Disabled Women Are Still Being Sterilized in Europe
articles.snippet: Governments have declared the practice a human rights violation. But they have made exceptions that are divisive among parents, doctors and social workers.
articles.abstract: Governments have declared the practice a human rights violation. But they have made exceptions that are divisive among parents, doctors and social workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anita cannot speak or comprehend complex information. At 28, she communicates mostly with facial expressions and baby-like sounds. When excited, she washes her hands. When her periods cause cramping and pain, she moans and agitates, unable to understand.

articles.headline: In This Atlanta Suburb, Teens Taste Freedom at 10 M.P.H.
articles.snippet: In Peachtree City, Ga., golf carts are everywhere, giving young people in particular an early chance to take life by the wheel.
articles.abstract: In Peachtree City, Ga., golf carts are everywhere, giving young people in particular an early chance to take life by the wheel.
articles.lead_paragraph: A regular golf cart has no turn signals, no radio, no protection from the elements other than a thin roof and rain flaps. Press the pedal to the floor and it can maybe — maybe — accelerate to 15 miles per hour.
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas and Gabriela Bhaskar

articles.headline: Gaza Civilians, Under Israeli Barrage, Are Being Killed at Historic Pace
articles.snippet: Even a conservative assessment of the reported Gaza casualty figures shows that the rate of death during Israel’s assault has few precedents in this century, experts say.
articles.abstract: Even a conservative assessment of the reported Gaza casualty figures shows that the rate of death during Israel’s assault has few precedents in this century, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel has cast the deaths of civilians in the Gaza Strip as a regrettable but unavoidable part of modern conflict, pointing to the heavy human toll from military campaigns the United States itself once waged in Iraq and Syria.

articles.headline: A Troubling Trump Pardon and a Link to the Kushners
articles.snippet: A commutation for a drug smuggler named Jonathan Braun had broader implications than previously known. It puts new focus on how Donald Trump would use his clemency powers in a second term.
articles.abstract: A commutation for a drug smuggler named Jonathan Braun had broader implications than previously known. It puts new focus on how Donald Trump would use his clemency powers in a second term.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even amid the uproar over President Donald J. Trump’s freewheeling use of his pardon powers at the end of his term, one commutation stood out.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Members of Congress Head for the Exits, Many Citing Dysfunction
articles.snippet: More than three dozen incumbents have announced they will not seek re-election next year. Some are running for other offices, while others intend to leave Congress altogether.
articles.abstract: More than three dozen incumbents have announced they will not seek re-election next year. Some are running for other offices, while others intend to leave Congress altogether.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eleven are running for the Senate. Five for state or local office. One for president of the United States. Another is resigning to become a university president. And more and more say they are hanging up their hats in public office altogether.

articles.headline: Can Taiwan Continue to Fight Off Chinese Disinformation?
articles.snippet: Ahead of a presidential election in January, Taiwanese fact checkers and watchdogs say they are ready for Beijing. But they are still worried.
articles.abstract: Ahead of a presidential election in January, Taiwanese fact checkers and watchdogs say they are ready for Beijing. But they are still worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: Suspicious videos that began circulating in Taiwan this month seemed to show the country’s leader advertising cryptocurrency investments.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu, Amy Chang Chien and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: U.S. Troops Still Train on Weapons With Known Risk of Brain Injury
articles.snippet: Pentagon researchers say weapons like shoulder-fired rockets expose troops who fire them to blast waves far above safety limits, but they remain in wide use.
articles.abstract: Pentagon researchers say weapons like shoulder-fired rockets expose troops who fire them to blast waves far above safety limits, but they remain in wide use.
articles.lead_paragraph: A blast shattered the stillness of a meadow in the Ozark Mountains on an autumn afternoon. Then another, and another, and another, until the whole meadow was in flames.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Kenny Holston

articles.headline: As Hamas Releases More Hostages, Longer Cease-Fire Appears Possible
articles.snippet: A third group of captives released from Gaza included a 4-year-old dual American-Israeli citizen whose parents were killed in the Hamas attack on Oct. 7.
articles.abstract: A third group of captives released from Gaza included a 4-year-old dual American-Israeli citizen whose parents were killed in the Hamas attack on Oct. 7.
articles.lead_paragraph: A third group of Gaza Strip hostages, including a 4-year-old American girl whose parents were killed in the Hamas raids on Israel, was freed on Sunday, raising the prospect more captives could be set free and a fragile truce extended.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee, Isabel Kershner and Aaron Boxerman

articles.headline: How Your Child’s Online Mistake Can Ruin Your Digital Life
articles.snippet: Google has a zero-tolerance policy for child abuse content. The scanning process can sometimes go awry and tar innocent individuals as abusers.
articles.abstract: Google has a zero-tolerance policy for child abuse content. The scanning process can sometimes go awry and tar innocent individuals as abusers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jennifer Watkins got a message from YouTube saying her channel was being shut down, she wasn’t initially worried. She didn’t use YouTube, after all.

articles.headline: In Countdown to Iowa, Trump Is Coasting, as DeSantis and Haley Clash
articles.snippet: The former president’s chief rivals are running low on time to make a statement in Iowa’s caucuses, which could determine whether the Republicans’ nominating contest is seriously contested at all.
articles.abstract: The former president’s chief rivals are running low on time to make a statement in Iowa’s caucuses, which could determine whether the Republicans’ nominating contest is seriously contested at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Negative mailers are overstuffing Iowa mailboxes. Attack ads are cluttering the airwaves. And door knockers are fanning out from Des Moines to Dubuque and everywhere in between.

articles.headline: Russian Women Protest Long Deployments for Soldiers in Ukraine
articles.snippet: “Make way for someone else,” a new grass-roots movement demands as women challenge the official argument that the mobilized troops are needed in combat indefinitely.
articles.abstract: “Make way for someone else,” a new grass-roots movement demands as women challenge the official argument that the mobilized troops are needed in combat indefinitely.
articles.lead_paragraph: The woman in the video, her face blurred, gave a blunt assessment of Russian military policy: Soldiers mobilized over a year ago to fight in Ukraine deserved to come home. Why weren’t they?
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

articles.headline: Biden Hopes to Alter the Trajectory of the War as Hostages Are Released
articles.snippet: At the president’s urging, the temporary truce between Israel and Hamas was extended two more days. The challenge is what comes next.
articles.abstract: At the president’s urging, the temporary truce between Israel and Hamas was extended two more days. The challenge is what comes next.
articles.lead_paragraph: After seven weeks of struggling with a crisis that defies easy solutions, President Biden could take solace in saving a single 4-year-old girl whose parents were killed in the Oct. 7 terrorist attack on Israel.

articles.headline: Inside U.S. Efforts to Untangle an A.I. Giant’s Ties to China
articles.snippet: American spy agencies have warned about the Emirati firm G42 and its work with large Chinese companies that U.S. officials consider security threats.
articles.abstract: American spy agencies have warned about the Emirati firm G42 and its work with large Chinese companies that U.S. officials consider security threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the secretive national security adviser of the United Arab Emirates, Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed, visited the White House in June, his American counterpart, Jake Sullivan, raised a delicate issue: G42, an artificial intelligence firm controlled by the sheikh that American officials believe is hiding the extent of its work with China.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Edward Wong
